chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret
sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे |
ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ||१||
transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca |
idaṁ tu te guhyatamaṁ pravakṣyāmy anasūyave |
jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt ||1||
translation: The Supreme Lord said: To you, who are free from envy, I shall now reveal this most profound secret knowledge, combined with realized experience, knowing which you shall be liberated from all misfortune.
commentary:
This opening verse of the ninth chapter marks a significant transition in Krishna's teaching. Having established Arjuna's qualification through the previous eight chapters, Krishna now promises to reveal the 'guhyatamam' - the most secret or profound knowledge. The term 'anasūyave' (free from envy or fault-finding) is crucial, indicating that this supreme knowledge can only be received by one who approaches it with faith and without a critical, doubting attitude. This quality of the student is essential for receiving the highest spiritual truths.

Krishna distinguishes between 'jñāna' (theoretical knowledge) and 'vijñāna' (experiential or realized knowledge). The combination of both is necessary for complete understanding. Mere intellectual comprehension without direct realization remains incomplete, while experience without proper understanding lacks direction. This verse promises that the knowledge to be imparted will lead to liberation from 'aśubha' - all inauspiciousness, suffering, and the cycle of birth and death. The chapter that follows will reveal Krishna's divine nature, his all-pervading presence, and the supreme devotion (bhakti) that leads to ultimate union with the Divine.

The designation of this knowledge as 'royal' (rāja-vidyā) and 'royal secret' (rāja-guhya) suggests its supremacy among all forms of knowledge. It is called royal because it is the king of all sciences, easily performed, purifying in effect, and everlasting in its results. This sets the tone for one of the most devotionally rich chapters of the Gita, where Krishna will reveal his cosmic form and the path of loving devotion.
speaker: Krishna
